awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: BPA Replacement with Non-Toxic Biobased Monomers
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL:

Many chemicals used in the plastics industry today are known to be toxic with adverse effects on human health and the environment. The objective of this SusChEM research project is to replace a well-known endocrine disrupting (ED) chemical used extensively in some plastics, coatings and adhesives called Bisphenol-A (BPA).  BPA will be replaced with new biobased substitutes that will have the following important attributes: (a) Renewable Resources: Be synthesized using chemicals derived from renewable resources such as lignin, which is the world's most abundant renewable resource from trees and plants; (b) Properties: Have similar high performance properties to petroleum-based chemicals when used in such high volume applications as food containers, polycarbonates, composite resins and epoxy adhesives; (c) Toxicity:  Have minimal impact on human health and the environment and have a low carbon-footprint; (d) Cost: Be produced in high volumes at low cost for the coatings, composites, automotive and renewable energy fields.  This grand intellectual challenge will be tackled in a unique manner using a multidisciplinary approach which optimally integrates green chemistry, polymer science, structure-property relations, toxicity and renewable resources. 


TECHNICAL:

The objective of this SusChEM research project is to replace a well-known endocrine disrupting (ED) monomer, Bisphenol-A (BPA), with a library of biobased substitutes such as Bisguaiacol-F (BGF) that will have the following important attributes: (a) Be synthesized using monomers from renewable resources such as guaiacol and vanillin from lignin; (b) Have similar thermal and mechanical properties to petroleum-based chemicals when used with co-monomers in high-performance polycarbonates, composite resins and adhesives; (c) Have low ED and environmental toxicity and (d) Be produced in high volumes at low cost for the coatings, composites, automotive food packaging and renewable energy fields. The project involves synthesis, polymer characterization, materials structure-properties, and computational and experimental toxicity studies.  The greatest sustainability impact of this research will come from providing a non-toxic alternative to BPA from renewable resources that will both ensure future supplies of high-performance plastics and composites while bolstering the high volumes needed for the food packaging industry, renewable energy development in the wind turbine industry and the next generation of composite-based, fuel efficient, light-weight automobiles.

por.por_cntn:
The use of bio-based and bio-inspired feedstocks for the generation of polymers unlocks potentially sustainable (more environmentally friendly) routes to the fabrication of next-generation materials, membranes, and devices. In this project, we use lignin as our feedstock of choice, primarily because of (1) its aromatic nature that can imbue materials with structural integrity in a similar manner to which it provides mechanical strength to trees (and plants), (2) its current under-utilization as a waste product from biorefineries and pulp & paper mills that typically burn it as heat, (3) its high abundance, and (4) its relatively low cost. Furthermore, the lignin-derived and lignin-inspired molecules used herein have chemical structures that differ slightly from petrochemical-based analogues. These differences do not have a significant impact on thermal and mechanical properties; however, they have a substantial impact on the chemicals? endocrine-disruption potential (leading to marked reductions in estrogen activity). In particular, we envision these compounds as capable of producing polymers that are functionally similar to bisphenol-A (BPA)-based macromolecules, but without the detrimental human health and environmental hazards. 

 

Intellectual Merit:

Through the National Science Foundation's SusCheM program, we have generated several novel, bio-based, high-performance alternatives to BPA. We accomplished this task through a multidisciplinary approach that integrated green chemistry, understanding of structure-property relationships, chemical toxicity, and renewable (bio-based) resource utilization.  We used lignin, which is a common waste product from biorefineries and the pulp & paper industry, as the renewable feedstock and inspiration for our materials. As a result of the work conducted in this project, we have generated a new class of chemical building blocks that have similar performance characteristics to BPA (thermal, mechanical, flow, solubility); however, these new, bio-based components were found to be much less endocrine disrupting via analysis by two developmental assays. Furthermore, the polymers generated from these BPA-alternatives demonstrated the appropriate thermal and mechanical property spectrum for use in applications ranging from liners of food packaging, to adhesives, to high-temperature membranes for water and air purification. Key results were highlighted in multiple publications in the peer-reviewed literature, multiple patents and patent applications, oral and poster presentations to the scientific and local community, and collaborative scientific activities with other academic and industrial groups, including small businesses.

 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to the design of new, high-performance materials with reduced endocrine disruption potential (reduced toxicity to humans and animals), these studies also led to greater understanding of new cell-based, animal-free assays that can be used to assess materials/compound toxicity. Additionally, we engaged in a variety of educational and outreach activities that had a substantial and positive impact on the community.  For example, we hosted a booth representing our University at the Gravity Arts and Science Festival sponsored by a local nonprofit organization in Wilmington, DE. Over 300 low-income K-12 students attended the event to participate in hands-on science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics (STEAM) learning, working with circuit boards containing re-purposed components from bananas, single-use plastics, and other materials. We also developed education modules for two summer camps, held on campus, for elementary school children.  One module, on the sustainability of food, used hands-on activities to teach students about lifecycle analysis and calorimetry to help determine which food sources provide the most energy with the lowest carbon footprint. The module is now part of the University learning library. A second module, on blood clotting, taught pre-K-5th graders about how the body responds to cuts through clotting, by demonstrating the phenomena with the transition of sodium alginate solutions to cross-linked gels by replacing sodium ions with calcium ions to induce ionic cross-linking.
